title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.79 billion government concessional loan for the Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#52873)
description: On November 14, 2016, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 1,791,608,000 government concessional loan (GCL) for the Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The GCL went ‘into effect’ on May 8, 2017. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the GCL to finance a $280 million engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract (commercial contract) between Dhaka Water Supply & Sewerage Authority and Hydro China International Engineering Co. Ltd, which was signed on November 23, 2014. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 31% (RMB 556,633,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2019, 48% (RMB 860,970,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 61.5% (RMB 1,102,297,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.    The Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant is located in Dasherkandi, Dhaka (the capital of Bangladesh), on the eastern side of the Gojaria River. The plant was designed to mainly deal with wastewater in Desherkandi, Hatirjheel, Gulshan, Banani, and Badda in order to eliminate the pollution of the Balu River. The project involved the construction of an off-site sewage lifting pumping station, a 4.8 km sewage conveyance trunk pipe (sewage transport pipe), the main sewage treatment plant which can process 500,000 tons of sewage per day, and a sludge drying-incineration system with a processing capacity of 580 tons per day. Upon completion, the project was expected to provide modern sewerage service to about 5 million people of Gulshan, Banani, Baridhara, Bashundhara, parliament, and adjoining areas including Hatirjheel of the city.   Chengdu Engineering Corporation — a subsidiary of Hydro China Corporation (PowerChina) — was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was originally scheduled to begin in January 2011 and end in December 2013, but its launch was delayed to insufficient funding. Construction eventually began on August 19, 2018. The project was initially planned to reach completion by December 2019. However, by November 2020, the project’s expected completion date was pushed back to 2021. Project implementation delays included dengue fever, terrorist attacks, and the COVID-19 epidemic. The sewage treatment plant started trial operations in December 2021 and a project handover certificate was issued on March 31, 2022. Then, on April 1, 2022, the sewage treatment plant went into operation. Chengdu Engineering Corporation is responsible for one year of operations and maintenance at the plant. The Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant is reportedly the first and the largest modern sewage treatment plant in Bangladesh, the largest single sewage treatment plant in South Asia, and the first modern sludge drying-incineration in Bangladesh.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 达舍尔甘地污水处理项目. 2. Hydro China International Engineering Co. Ltd is a a subsidiary of Hydro China Corporation. 3. The Government of Bangladesh’s loan identification number for the GCL is L1120161014B. 4. For the umbrella record that captures multiple Chinese loans signed on November 14, 2016, see Project ID#52873. The other two projects that fall under this umbrella record are Project ID#34433 and Project ID#38342. 5. The Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project should not be confused with Project ID#34019. 6. Dasherkandi is sometimes spelled ‘Dasher Kandi.’ Chinese sources usually use the terms Dasher Kandhi' or 'Dasher Gandhi'; most sources from Bangladesh spell the project as 'Dasherkanhi’
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 1.79 billion government concessional loan for the Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#52873)

# Description
On November 14, 2016, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 1,791,608,000 government concessional loan (GCL) for the Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The GCL went ‘into effect’ on May 8, 2017. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the GCL to finance a $280 million engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract (commercial contract) between Dhaka Water Supply & Sewerage Authority and Hydro China International Engineering Co. Ltd, which was signed on November 23, 2014. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 31% (RMB 556,633,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2019, 48% (RMB 860,970,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 61.5% (RMB 1,102,297,000 out of RMB 1,791,608,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.    The Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant is located in Dasherkandi, Dhaka (the capital of Bangladesh), on the eastern side of the Gojaria River. The plant was designed to mainly deal with wastewater in Desherkandi, Hatirjheel, Gulshan, Banani, and Badda in order to eliminate the pollution of the Balu River. The project involved the construction of an off-site sewage lifting pumping station, a 4.8 km sewage conveyance trunk pipe (sewage transport pipe), the main sewage treatment plant which can process 500,000 tons of sewage per day, and a sludge drying-incineration system with a processing capacity of 580 tons per day. Upon completion, the project was expected to provide modern sewerage service to about 5 million people of Gulshan, Banani, Baridhara, Bashundhara, parliament, and adjoining areas including Hatirjheel of the city.   Chengdu Engineering Corporation — a subsidiary of Hydro China Corporation (PowerChina) — was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was originally scheduled to begin in January 2011 and end in December 2013, but its launch was delayed to insufficient funding. Construction eventually began on August 19, 2018. The project was initially planned to reach completion by December 2019. However, by November 2020, the project’s expected completion date was pushed back to 2021. Project implementation delays included dengue fever, terrorist attacks, and the COVID-19 epidemic. The sewage treatment plant started trial operations in December 2021 and a project handover certificate was issued on March 31, 2022. Then, on April 1, 2022, the sewage treatment plant went into operation. Chengdu Engineering Corporation is responsible for one year of operations and maintenance at the plant. The Dasherkandi Sewage Treatment Plant is reportedly the first and the largest modern sewage treatment plant in Bangladesh, the largest single sewage treatment plant in South Asia, and the first modern sludge drying-incineration in Bangladesh.
justification: Project focuses on water supply and sanitation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of sewage treatment plant, sewage conveyance system, and sludge processing facilities for urban wastewater management

title: Chinese Government provides $2 million grant for PPD Building Construction Project
description: On the 20th of March, 2016, the Vice-Minister of China’s National Health and Family Planning Commission (NPFPC) Wang Pei’an and PPD Executive Director Joe Thomas signed an agreement to donate US$ 2.3 million dollars to build the permanent headquarters for the Partners in Population Development (PPD), in Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  In addition to Chinese donation, the government of India and South Africa each donated US$100,000 dollars to the construction of the headquarters of PPD.   On the 24th of October, 2017, the construction of the headquarters had finished and is ready to open.   PS: The PPD is a south-south collaboration forum of 26 developing countries. Members include Bangladesh, China, India, Benin, Colombia, Egypt, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Indonesia, Jordan, Kenya, Mali, Mexico, Morocco, Nigeria, Pakistan, Senegal, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tunisia, Uganda, Vietnam, Yemen and Zimbabwe.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2 million grant for PPD Building Construction Project

# Description
On the 20th of March, 2016, the Vice-Minister of China’s National Health and Family Planning Commission (NPFPC) Wang Pei’an and PPD Executive Director Joe Thomas signed an agreement to donate US$ 2.3 million dollars to build the permanent headquarters for the Partners in Population Development (PPD), in Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  In addition to Chinese donation, the government of India and South Africa each donated US$100,000 dollars to the construction of the headquarters of PPD.   On the 24th of October, 2017, the construction of the headquarters had finished and is ready to open.   PS: The PPD is a south-south collaboration forum of 26 developing countries. Members include Bangladesh, China, India, Benin, Colombia, Egypt, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Indonesia, Jordan, Kenya, Mali, Mexico, Morocco, Nigeria, Pakistan, Senegal, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tunisia, Uganda, Vietnam, Yemen and Zimbabwe.
justification: Project involves construction of a headquarters building for a population development organization, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of permanent headquarters for Partners in Population Development (PPD), social infrastructure focus

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 945,551,000 government concessional loan for construction of IV Tier National Data Center Project in Kaliakoir
description: On April 15, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 945,551,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Tier IV National Data Center Project in Kaliakoir. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, and a 0.2% commitment fee (service charge). The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a $154 million commercial contract between ZTE Corporation and the Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC). According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 56.1% (RMB 530,620,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2018, 82.1% (RMB 776,875,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2019, 100% (RMB 945,551,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 100% (RMB 945,551,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2018, June 30, 2019, June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.   The purpose of this project was to build a flagship Tier IV Data Center in the Kaliakair Upazila within Gazipur District and the Division of Dhaka to store and process a large amount of official data.  ZTE Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation and its work was overseen by the Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC). As of 2017, the data center had been constructed, but the operational status of the data center was delayed by U.S. government sanctions on ZTE. In October 2018, the data center underwent operational tests.   The project was officially completed on November 29, 2019. The Bangladesh National Data Center (NDC) is the first national data center that received both the UPTIME Tier IV design certification and facility certification in the country and is also the first data center in South Asia that got UPTIME Tier IV facility certification. In addition, the data center passed all the test items of the Uptime Tier IV construction certification, thereby being highly appraised by the Uptime Institute. During the construction of the data center, the ZTE construction team reportedly overcame a series of challenges, such as inconvenient transportation, unstable power supply, and bad weather.
staff_comments: 1. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for this China Eximbank GCL is L1120160415A. 2. The Chinese project title is 建设孟国家数据中心.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 945,551,000 government concessional loan for construction of IV Tier National Data Center Project in Kaliakoir

# Description
On April 15, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 945,551,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Tier IV National Data Center Project in Kaliakoir. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, and a 0.2% commitment fee (service charge). The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a $154 million commercial contract between ZTE Corporation and the Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC). According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 56.1% (RMB 530,620,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2018, 82.1% (RMB 776,875,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2019, 100% (RMB 945,551,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 100% (RMB 945,551,000 out of RMB 945,551,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2018, June 30, 2019, June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.   The purpose of this project was to build a flagship Tier IV Data Center in the Kaliakair Upazila within Gazipur District and the Division of Dhaka to store and process a large amount of official data.  ZTE Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation and its work was overseen by the Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC). As of 2017, the data center had been constructed, but the operational status of the data center was delayed by U.S. government sanctions on ZTE. In October 2018, the data center underwent operational tests.   The project was officially completed on November 29, 2019. The Bangladesh National Data Center (NDC) is the first national data center that received both the UPTIME Tier IV design certification and facility certification in the country and is also the first data center in South Asia that got UPTIME Tier IV facility certification. In addition, the data center passed all the test items of the Uptime Tier IV construction certification, thereby being highly appraised by the Uptime Institute. During the construction of the data center, the ZTE construction team reportedly overcame a series of challenges, such as inconvenient transportation, unstable power supply, and bad weather.
justification: Project focuses on data center construction without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Tier IV National Data Center Project, data storage and processing focus, no mention of renewable energy or environmental impacts

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan for Procurement of 6 Oil Vessels Project (Linked to Project ID#55046 and #38342)
description: On November 14, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 1,200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Procurement of 6 Oil Vessels Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, and a 0.2% commitment fee (service charge). The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a $184.5 million commercial contract between Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC) and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, which was signed in October 2016. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 58.4% (RMB 701,140,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2018, 96% (RMB 1,152,910,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2019, 99.9% (RMB 1,199,990,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 99.9% (RMB 1,199,990,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2018, June 30, 2019, June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.   The purpose of the project was for Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC) to purchase 3 bulk oil tankers and 3 oil carriers from the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. Each ship was expected to have a load of 39,000 tons. The 3 new bulk oil tankers and 3 oil carriers were to be built by the Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) Ltd. for the Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC), and they were expected to be delivered in 2018 to join the BSC's existing fleet of 8 ships. The keel laying for the first vessel was concluded on January 30, 2018. The second vessel — a bulk oil tanker — was launched from the slipway of the New Yangzi shipyard on June 14, 2018. Two additional vessels were launched on July 25, 2018. Another vessel was launched on February 2, 2018. On January 22, 2019, a 39000DWT tanker was successfully delivered to BSC.
staff_comments: 1. The Government of Bangladesh's loan identification number for the China Eximbank GCL is L1120161014A.  2. This project is also known as the 'Purchase of 6 Oil Ships Project'.  3. Given that the sixth vessel was successfully delivered to BSC on January 22, 2019, AidData has status-coded the project as complete and set the project completion date to January 22, 2019.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan for Procurement of 6 Oil Vessels Project (Linked to Project ID#55046 and #38342)

# Description
On November 14, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 1,200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Procurement of 6 Oil Vessels Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, and a 0.2% commitment fee (service charge). The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a $184.5 million commercial contract between Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC) and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, which was signed in October 2016. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 58.4% (RMB 701,140,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2018, 96% (RMB 1,152,910,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2019, 99.9% (RMB 1,199,990,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2020, and 99.9% (RMB 1,199,990,000 out of RMB 1,200,000,000) as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2018, June 30, 2019, June 30, 2020 or June 30, 2021.   The purpose of the project was for Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC) to purchase 3 bulk oil tankers and 3 oil carriers from the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. Each ship was expected to have a load of 39,000 tons. The 3 new bulk oil tankers and 3 oil carriers were to be built by the Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) Ltd. for the Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC), and they were expected to be delivered in 2018 to join the BSC's existing fleet of 8 ships. The keel laying for the first vessel was concluded on January 30, 2018. The second vessel — a bulk oil tanker — was launched from the slipway of the New Yangzi shipyard on June 14, 2018. Two additional vessels were launched on July 25, 2018. Another vessel was launched on February 2, 2018. On January 22, 2019, a 39000DWT tanker was successfully delivered to BSC.
justification: Project involves procurement of oil vessels for transporting oil, directly supporting fossil fuel infrastructure
evidence: Purchase of 3 bulk oil tankers and 3 oil carriers, each with 39,000 ton capacity, for Bangladesh Shipping Corporation

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 528 million in grant funding for 8th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge Construction Project over the Kocha River
description: On March 7, 2016, the Chinese Government issued an RMB 300 million grant to the Government of Bangladesh for the 8th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge Construction Project. The Chinese Government reportedly increased its grant commitment to RMB 528 million at some point. However, the exact date and nature of this grant funding increase are unclear.  The Government of Bangladesh reported that the project would cost a total of 11.453 billion BDT (taka), of which 7.052 billion BDT (taka) will be granted by the Chinese Government.   The purpose of the project was to construct a 1500 meter bridge that runs over the Kocha River in Bekutia within Pirojpur District. The bridge is located at the 12th km of Rajapur-Naikati-Bekutia Pirojpur Road (Z-8702 or the Rajapur-Pirojpur Expressway). Prior to project completion, a ferry was operated on the Kocha river and it took more than an hour to cross the river.  Upon completion, it was expected that the bridge will play an important role in accelerating the movement of people and goods between Barisal and Khulna divisions.  China Railway Major Bridge Reconnaissance & Design Institute Co., Ltd. (BRDI), a subsidiary of China Railway Group Limited, was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Construction began on November 1, 2018, and the originally expected project completion date was January 1, 2021. The bridge was ultimately completed and officially inaugurated on September 4, 2022.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Kocha Bridge Construction Project or the Bekutia Bridge over Kocha River on Perojpur-Jhalokathi Road, Pirojpur District Project.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 528 million in grant funding for 8th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge Construction Project over the Kocha River

# Description
On March 7, 2016, the Chinese Government issued an RMB 300 million grant to the Government of Bangladesh for the 8th Bangladesh-China Friendship Bridge Construction Project. The Chinese Government reportedly increased its grant commitment to RMB 528 million at some point. However, the exact date and nature of this grant funding increase are unclear.  The Government of Bangladesh reported that the project would cost a total of 11.453 billion BDT (taka), of which 7.052 billion BDT (taka) will be granted by the Chinese Government.   The purpose of the project was to construct a 1500 meter bridge that runs over the Kocha River in Bekutia within Pirojpur District. The bridge is located at the 12th km of Rajapur-Naikati-Bekutia Pirojpur Road (Z-8702 or the Rajapur-Pirojpur Expressway). Prior to project completion, a ferry was operated on the Kocha river and it took more than an hour to cross the river.  Upon completion, it was expected that the bridge will play an important role in accelerating the movement of people and goods between Barisal and Khulna divisions.  China Railway Major Bridge Reconnaissance & Design Institute Co., Ltd. (BRDI), a subsidiary of China Railway Group Limited, was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Construction began on November 1, 2018, and the originally expected project completion date was January 1, 2021. The bridge was ultimately completed and officially inaugurated on September 4, 2022.
justification: Bridge construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 1500 meter bridge over Kocha River, transportation infrastructure focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 500 miillion grant for acquisition of 1,000 fire department motorcycles
description: On October 14, 2016, China committed to grant 500 million RMB (approximately $73.29 million) for the modernization of Bangladesh's Fire Service and Civil Defence. The financial and technical cooperation agreement was signed during President Xi Jinping’s visit to Bangladesh, and is said to be part of the project of Disaster Emergency Operation Centre and Information Platform. The grant will provide for 1000 ‘water mist fire motorcycles’ fitted with modern technologies. The motorcycles will be able to maneuver through Dhaka's crowded streets.  The PDF Named "অনুদাৈ ও ঋণচুতির িাতিকা" or "List of Grants and Loans" is a part of Bangladesh's Economic Relations Division's 2017 Annual report. This PDF confirms the signing date. Chinese Commerce Ministry website reports in August, 2018 that a quality examination of the motorcycles was conducted on August 13-14, 2018, and the shipment is scheduled to be shipped from Tianjin Port on August 29 and is expected to arrive in Bangladesh at the end of September. On May 2nd, 2019 in the capital of Dhaka, the intergovernmental handover ceremony occurred where the motorcycles were provided as aid. The reports also identifies the implementing agency as the Jiujiang Fire Fighting Equipment Limited Company(九江消防装备有限公司).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 500 miillion grant for acquisition of 1,000 fire department motorcycles

# Description
On October 14, 2016, China committed to grant 500 million RMB (approximately $73.29 million) for the modernization of Bangladesh's Fire Service and Civil Defence. The financial and technical cooperation agreement was signed during President Xi Jinping’s visit to Bangladesh, and is said to be part of the project of Disaster Emergency Operation Centre and Information Platform. The grant will provide for 1000 ‘water mist fire motorcycles’ fitted with modern technologies. The motorcycles will be able to maneuver through Dhaka's crowded streets.  The PDF Named "অনুদাৈ ও ঋণচুতির িাতিকা" or "List of Grants and Loans" is a part of Bangladesh's Economic Relations Division's 2017 Annual report. This PDF confirms the signing date. Chinese Commerce Ministry website reports in August, 2018 that a quality examination of the motorcycles was conducted on August 13-14, 2018, and the shipment is scheduled to be shipped from Tianjin Port on August 29 and is expected to arrive in Bangladesh at the end of September. On May 2nd, 2019 in the capital of Dhaka, the intergovernmental handover ceremony occurred where the motorcycles were provided as aid. The reports also identifies the implementing agency as the Jiujiang Fire Fighting Equipment Limited Company(九江消防装备有限公司).
justification: Project focuses on disaster response and civil defense modernization without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Grant for fire department motorcycles, modernization of Bangladesh's Fire Service and Civil Defence, disaster emergency operations focus

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.93 billion government concessional loan for Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB (Linked to Project ID#92465)
description: In November 2016, the Government of Bangladesh’s National Economic Commission Executive Committee (ECNEC) approved the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under the Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). Then, On August 11, 2017, China Eximbank reportedly expressed interest in financing the project and invited Bangladesh’s Ministry of Finance to submit a loan application. On June 7, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed two loan agreements for the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB: an RMB 1,930,000,000 ($279.71 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement and a $686.571 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement. The GCL, which is captured via Project ID#54399, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.2% commitment fee. The PBC, which is captured via Project ID#92465, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 3% interest rate, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. The PBC and GCL proceeds were to be used by the borrower to finance a $1,141,200,116.04 commercial (EPC) contract between PGCB and a consortium consisting of CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company, which was signed on October 10, 2016. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 51.8% (RMB 1,000,101,000 out of RMB 1,930,000,000) as of June 30, 2021 but the PBC had disbursed as of June 30, 2021. The borrower had not made any repayments under the GCL or PBC as of June 30, 2021.  The purpose of the project is to construct 989.7 kilometers of new transmission lines and install 41 new substations in Dhaka and Mymensingh. More specifically, the project involves the following components:  (a) 400 kV Kaliakoir-Mymensingh transmission line: 100km  (b) 230 kV transmission line: 330.20 km  (c) 132 kV transmission line: 334.50km  (d) Conductor up gradation of existing 132 kV transmission line: 225 km  (e) 400/132 kV new Substation: 01 Nos (1x 650 MVA) (f) Construction of new 230/132 kV substations: 12 nos. (total 9200 MVA)  (g) Capacity up gradation of existing 230/132 kV substations: 7 nos. (3035 MVA)  (h) Construction of new 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos. (7404 MVA)  (i) Capacity up gradation of existing 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos.(8044 MVA)  (j) Extension of Existing 400 kV Substation: 1 nos  (k) Extension of Existing 230 kV Substation: 3 nos (l) Extension of Existing 132 kV Substation: 14 nos  (m) Renovation of existing substations: 05 Nos.  (n) To construct new Specialized Engineering Facilities: 7 nos.  Components (a) and (b) involve 1. Construction of Kaliakoir - Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 400 kV double circuit line: 100 km 2. Construction of Barapukuria (New) - Rangpur Substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 40km 3. Construction of Kaliakoir - Tangail Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 4. Construction of Khulna (S) substation - Khulna (Central) 230 kV substation (proposed) double circuit line: 0.2 km 5. Construction of Mymensingh substation (proposed)- Phulpur AIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 35 km 6. Construction of Barisal(N) - Patuakhali 230kV double circuit line: 55km 7. Construction of Bibiyana 230 kV substation - Sylhet (S) 230 kV GIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 8. Construction of Sylhet(S) Substation (proposed) - Sylhet (E) Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 10 km 9. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (S) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 16 km 10. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 7km 11. Construction of Bhulta - Jalshiri 230kV double circuit line: 12km (Initially to be charged at 132kV). 12. Construction of Sylhet (E) substation (proposed) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 16km 13. Construction of Kaliakoir - Kabirpur Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 15km 14. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ishurdi - Ghorasal 230 kV double circuit line at new Dhamrai substation: 1km 15. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Comilla (N) - Meghnaghat 230 kV double circuit line at new Gazaria substation: 1km 16. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bheramara HVDC - Khulna (S) 230kV Line at Jessore: 8 km 17. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bibiyana - Fenchuganj 230 kV double circuit line at new Bibiyana substation: 1km 18. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Barapukuria (N) substation: 10km 19. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ghorasal - Rampura 230 kV double circuit line at new Madhobdi substation: 1km 20. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Palashbari substation: 22 km.    Components (e) an and (f) involve 1. Construction of 400/132/33 kV AIS Substation with 2x225/325 MVA & 4x20 MVA transformer at Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 2. Construction of 230 kV AIS Switching station at Barapukuria(N) 3. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x150 MVA & 2x50/75 MVA transformers at Bibiyana 4. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer at Khulna Central 5. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Madhobdi 6. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 1x50/75 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Palashbari 7. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 2x80/120 MVA transformer at Gazaria 8. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer atDhamrai 9. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Jessore 10. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Rangpur 11. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 3x300/450 MVA transformer at Kabirpur 12. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Tangail 13. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Sylhet (S).  CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company are the EPC contractors responsible for implementation. Project implementation officially commenced on February 16, 2021. As of August 2021, the project had achieved an 18.9% completion rate. By December 2021, land for 72 of the 92 power substations supported by the project had been handed over to the CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC consortium and soil testing was underway for another 17 substations. The project was originally scheduled for completion in June 2024. However, it is running behind schedule due to the Covid-19 pandemic and other factors. The CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC Consortium was unable to provide the necessary manpower. PGCB was also asked to provide 370 staff members to support the implementation project. It provided only 60 — much lower than the requirement. Another obstacle has been the lack of funds for compensation to the local people who are being affected by the implementation of the project. Upon completion, the project is expected to add 10,000 MW power transmission capacity to the PGCB network.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). The Chinese project title is 孟加拉国家电网公司电网升级改造项目 or 孟加拉国家电网公司电网升级改造项目 or 孟加拉国家电网升级改造交钥匙工程. 2. This project should not be confused with the Enhancement and Strengthening of Power Network in Eastern Region Project, also under PGCB, which is supported by the World Bank. 3. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the GCL is L1120200607A. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the PBC is B1120200607A. 4. The EPC consortium responsible for this project is known as the CCCE-Jiangsu ETERN-FEPEC consortium. Fujian Electric Power Company is a subsidiary of PowerChina.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 1.93 billion government concessional loan for Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB (Linked to Project ID#92465)

# Description
In November 2016, the Government of Bangladesh’s National Economic Commission Executive Committee (ECNEC) approved the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under the Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). Then, On August 11, 2017, China Eximbank reportedly expressed interest in financing the project and invited Bangladesh’s Ministry of Finance to submit a loan application. On June 7, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed two loan agreements for the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB: an RMB 1,930,000,000 ($279.71 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement and a $686.571 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement. The GCL, which is captured via Project ID#54399, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.2% commitment fee. The PBC, which is captured via Project ID#92465, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 3% interest rate, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. The PBC and GCL proceeds were to be used by the borrower to finance a $1,141,200,116.04 commercial (EPC) contract between PGCB and a consortium consisting of CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company, which was signed on October 10, 2016. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 51.8% (RMB 1,000,101,000 out of RMB 1,930,000,000) as of June 30, 2021 but the PBC had disbursed as of June 30, 2021. The borrower had not made any repayments under the GCL or PBC as of June 30, 2021.  The purpose of the project is to construct 989.7 kilometers of new transmission lines and install 41 new substations in Dhaka and Mymensingh. More specifically, the project involves the following components:  (a) 400 kV Kaliakoir-Mymensingh transmission line: 100km  (b) 230 kV transmission line: 330.20 km  (c) 132 kV transmission line: 334.50km  (d) Conductor up gradation of existing 132 kV transmission line: 225 km  (e) 400/132 kV new Substation: 01 Nos (1x 650 MVA) (f) Construction of new 230/132 kV substations: 12 nos. (total 9200 MVA)  (g) Capacity up gradation of existing 230/132 kV substations: 7 nos. (3035 MVA)  (h) Construction of new 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos. (7404 MVA)  (i) Capacity up gradation of existing 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos.(8044 MVA)  (j) Extension of Existing 400 kV Substation: 1 nos  (k) Extension of Existing 230 kV Substation: 3 nos (l) Extension of Existing 132 kV Substation: 14 nos  (m) Renovation of existing substations: 05 Nos.  (n) To construct new Specialized Engineering Facilities: 7 nos.  Components (a) and (b) involve 1. Construction of Kaliakoir - Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 400 kV double circuit line: 100 km 2. Construction of Barapukuria (New) - Rangpur Substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 40km 3. Construction of Kaliakoir - Tangail Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 4. Construction of Khulna (S) substation - Khulna (Central) 230 kV substation (proposed) double circuit line: 0.2 km 5. Construction of Mymensingh substation (proposed)- Phulpur AIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 35 km 6. Construction of Barisal(N) - Patuakhali 230kV double circuit line: 55km 7. Construction of Bibiyana 230 kV substation - Sylhet (S) 230 kV GIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 8. Construction of Sylhet(S) Substation (proposed) - Sylhet (E) Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 10 km 9. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (S) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 16 km 10. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 7km 11. Construction of Bhulta - Jalshiri 230kV double circuit line: 12km (Initially to be charged at 132kV). 12. Construction of Sylhet (E) substation (proposed) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 16km 13. Construction of Kaliakoir - Kabirpur Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 15km 14. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ishurdi - Ghorasal 230 kV double circuit line at new Dhamrai substation: 1km 15. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Comilla (N) - Meghnaghat 230 kV double circuit line at new Gazaria substation: 1km 16. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bheramara HVDC - Khulna (S) 230kV Line at Jessore: 8 km 17. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bibiyana - Fenchuganj 230 kV double circuit line at new Bibiyana substation: 1km 18. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Barapukuria (N) substation: 10km 19. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ghorasal - Rampura 230 kV double circuit line at new Madhobdi substation: 1km 20. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Palashbari substation: 22 km.    Components (e) an and (f) involve 1. Construction of 400/132/33 kV AIS Substation with 2x225/325 MVA & 4x20 MVA transformer at Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 2. Construction of 230 kV AIS Switching station at Barapukuria(N) 3. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x150 MVA & 2x50/75 MVA transformers at Bibiyana 4. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer at Khulna Central 5. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Madhobdi 6. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 1x50/75 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Palashbari 7. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 2x80/120 MVA transformer at Gazaria 8. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer atDhamrai 9. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Jessore 10. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Rangpur 11. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 3x300/450 MVA transformer at Kabirpur 12. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Tangail 13. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Sylhet (S).  CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company are the EPC contractors responsible for implementation. Project implementation officially commenced on February 16, 2021. As of August 2021, the project had achieved an 18.9% completion rate. By December 2021, land for 72 of the 92 power substations supported by the project had been handed over to the CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC consortium and soil testing was underway for another 17 substations. The project was originally scheduled for completion in June 2024. However, it is running behind schedule due to the Covid-19 pandemic and other factors. The CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC Consortium was unable to provide the necessary manpower. PGCB was also asked to provide 370 staff members to support the implementation project. It provided only 60 — much lower than the requirement. Another obstacle has been the lack of funds for compensation to the local people who are being affected by the implementation of the project. Upon completion, the project is expected to add 10,000 MW power transmission capacity to the PGCB network.
justification: Project focuses on transmission infrastructure without specifying energy sources, enabling both renewable and non-renewable power
evidence: Construction of 989.7 km of new transmission lines and 41 new substations, with no specific energy source mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.95 billion government concessional loan for Multi Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project (Linked to Project ID#52873 and #38342) [BRI]
description: On June 9, 2014, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Sheikh Hasina, visited China and the Chinese Government and the Government of Bangladesh signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the Multi-Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project. Then, on November 14, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed an RMB 1,950,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement and a $405.8 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement for the Multi-Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a grace period of 5 years, and a 0.2% commitment fee. The PBC carries the following terms: a 2% interest rate, a 20-year maturity, a grace period of 5 years, and a 0.2% commitment fee. Project ID#55046 captures the GCL, while Project ID#38342 captures the PBC. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the GCL and the PBC to finance a commercial contract between the Government of Bangladesh’s Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges and China Communication Construction Company (CCCC), which was signed in June 2015. The GCL had disbursed RMB 936,1890,000 as of June 30, 2018, RMB 1,557,869,000 as of June 30, 2019, RMB 1,950,000,000 as of June 30, 2020, and RMB 1,950,000,000 as of June 30, 2021. No repayments on the GCL had been made as of June 30, 2019 or June 30, 2021. As of June 30, 2021, the PBC had disbursed $165.559 million and no repayments had been made.   The purpose of the project, which is also known as the Multilane Karnaphuli Tunnel Project, is to construct a 3.4-kilometer-long, 10-meter-wide tunnel under the Karnaphuli River near the Port of Chittagong. The total length of the proposed tunnel will be around 9.092 kilometers, including a 3.40-kilometer tunnel under the Karnaphuli River with an approach road of 4.89 kilometers alongside 740 meters of bridges linking the main port city, and western side of the Karnaphuli along with the eastern side of the river. Upon completion, the tunnel will connect the port of Chittagong to the industrial area of the city and thereby relieve pressure on the three existing bridges. The total area of the project is 382.03 acres. More than 360.64 acres of land were acquired for the construction of roads and installments of utility lines. A total of 2,275 families are affected by this project, and 1,660 were given compensation. China Communication Construction Company (CCCC) is the general (EPC) contractor responsible for project implementation.   On November 24, 2015, the Executive Committee of the National Economic Council (Ecnec) approved the Multi-Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project. Construction began on February 24, 2017.    Two years later, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh officially inaugurated boring works on the tunnel on February 24, 2019. The project had achieved a 40% physical completion rate by May 2019, including the installation of over 150 meters of the first tunnel and much of the above-ground works. Then, on July 31, 2020, the project reached a key milestone with the completion of the first underwater, after a made-in-China super-diameter slurry-pressure-balance tunnel boring machine (TBM) broke through at the Karnaphuli River east bank working shaft.    The TBM, which is 94 meters long and weighs more than 2,200 tons, was developed by the Tianhe Mechanical Equipment Manufacturing Co. It was the first super-diameter slurry-pressure-balance TBM to be self-developed and exported by China. The TBM uses several self-developed technologies, such as an automatic mud water circulation system. As of October 2021, all boring-related work was completed — after the excavation of the second tube (from Anwara end of Chittagong to Patenga end) of the 3.315-km tunnel) — and the project had achieved a 73% physical completion rate. By November 2021, the project had achieved a 77.5% physical completion rate. On May 8, 2022, Harunur Rashid Chowdhury, Project Director of Karnaphuli Multilane Road Tunnel, sent a letter to the Bangladesh Bridge Authority (BBA). In it, he noted that Shanghai Port had remained closed since March 2022 due to Covid-19 and the Chinese Government’s zero-tolerance policy had affected the project’s progress: ‘It may be noted that […] most of the goods and equipment are being manufactured/procured from Shanghai. Therefore, the closure of the Shanghai Port is causing a delay in shipments. […] The goods and equipment planned to arrive in March [2022] are still not able to reach Chittagong Port to date. Subsequent shipments will also get affected on this account.’ In the letter, Harunur Rashid Chowdhury also asked the BBA to take up the issue with the Economic Relations Division (ERD) and arrange an extension of the China Eximbank loan availability period by six months until May 6, 2023. On May 7, 2022, Li Zheng, the CCCC Project Manager of the Karnaphuli Tunnel Project Site Office, acknowledged in a letter to Harunur Rashid Chowdhury that the delay in shipments from Shanghai was the result of China’s ‘zero Covid’ measures. Then, in June 2022, BBA announced that two sub-contractors hired CCCC to complete two project components — a management software system for BBA and the service area (east) — had violated their contractual obligations. According to a letter from Harunur Rashid Chowdhury, Project Director of Karnaphuli Multilane Road Tunnel, to the BBA, ‘CCCC was instructed to undertake this work, but they employed sub-contractors to do so.  CCCC selected these sub-contractors and is responsible for any default of the sub-contractors. […] Unfortunately, CCCC has not effectively monitored or exercised control over both these sub-contractors.’ The Multi-Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project was originally expected to reach completion by the end of 2020. However, in 2018, the project’s expected completion date was pushed back to December 4, 2022.    Upon completion, the underwater tunnel is expected to reduce the time it takes to drive from Hittagong Shah Amanat International Airport to the Hittagong industrial park from four hours to 20 minutes.
staff_comments: 1. This project is a part of the Belt and Road Initiative and one of a series of loans captured via Umbrella Project ID#52873. 2. Karnaphuli is sometimes also spelled as ‘Karnafuli’. 3. This project is also known as the Karnaphuli River Tunnel Project and the Karnaphuli Multilane Road Tunnel Project. The Chinese project title is 孟加拉国卡纳普里河底隧道项目. 4. The Government of Bangladesh’s loan identification number for the GCL is L1120161014C. The Government of Bangladesh’s loan identification number for the PBC is B1120161014A.
combined_text:

On May 8, 2022, Harunur Rashid Chowdhury, Project Director of Karnaphuli Multilane Road Tunnel, sent a letter to the Bangladesh Bridge Authority (BBA). In it, he noted that Shanghai Port had remained closed since March 2022 due to Covid-19 and the Chinese Government’s zero-tolerance policy had affected the project’s progress: ‘It may be noted that […] most of the goods and equipment are being manufactured/procured from Shanghai. Therefore, the closure of the Shanghai Port is causing a delay in shipments. […] The goods and equipment planned to arrive in March [2022] are still not able to reach Chittagong Port to date. Subsequent shipments will also get affected on this account.’ In the letter, Harunur Rashid Chowdhury also asked the BBA to take up the issue with the Economic Relations Division (ERD) and arrange an extension of the China Eximbank loan availability period by six months until May 6, 2023. On May 7, 2022, Li Zheng, the CCCC Project Manager of the Karnaphuli Tunnel Project Site Office, acknowledged in a letter to Harunur Rashid Chowdhury that the delay in shipments from Shanghai was the result of China’s ‘zero Covid’ measures. Then, in June 2022, BBA announced that two sub-contractors hired CCCC to complete two project components — a management software system for BBA and the service area (east) — had violated their contractual obligations. According to a letter from Harunur Rashid Chowdhury, Project Director of Karnaphuli Multilane Road Tunnel, to the BBA, ‘CCCC was instructed to undertake this work, but they employed sub-contractors to do so.  CCCC selected these sub-contractors and is responsible for any default of the sub-contractors. […] Unfortunately, CCCC has not effectively monitored or exercised control over both these sub-contractors.’ The Multi-Lane Road Tunnel under River Karnaphuli Project was originally expected to reach completion by the end of 2020. However, in 2018, the project’s expected completion date was pushed back to December 4, 2022. justification: The project is focused on transportation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of a 3.4-kilometer-long tunnel under the Karnaphuli River with approach roads and bridges, aimed at improving transportation efficiency and reducing travel time

title: China provides a grant for the provision of simultaneous translation equipment to International Convention Centre Construction (Linked to Project ID#33925, #33940)
description: In 2016, China gave a grant for the provision of simultaneous translation equipment to Bangabandhu International Convention Centre Construction, a Chinese government aided construction project in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Additionally, the grant was used to repair the large conference hall, repair the roof waterproofing, and increase the Chinese government's permanent aid sign and technical training for inspection and acceptance. China Construction Consulting Company implemented the changes. The project was completed on November 11, 2016.   This project is linked to project #33925, which captures the $100 RMB interest-free loan granted by the Chinese government to build Bangabandhu International Convention Centre and to project #33940, in which the Chinese government forgave RMB 11.099 million of debt related to the project.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援孟加拉国国际会议中心同传设备项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China provides a grant for the provision of simultaneous translation equipment to International Convention Centre Construction (Linked to Project ID#33925, #33940)

# Description
In 2016, China gave a grant for the provision of simultaneous translation equipment to Bangabandhu International Convention Centre Construction, a Chinese government aided construction project in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Additionally, the grant was used to repair the large conference hall, repair the roof waterproofing, and increase the Chinese government's permanent aid sign and technical training for inspection and acceptance. China Construction Consulting Company implemented the changes. The project was completed on November 11, 2016.   This project is linked to project #33925, which captures the $100 RMB interest-free loan granted by the Chinese government to build Bangabandhu International Convention Centre and to project #33940, in which the Chinese government forgave RMB 11.099 million of debt related to the project.
justification: Project focuses on providing translation equipment and facility repairs for a convention center, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Provision of simultaneous translation equipment, conference hall repairs, roof waterproofing repairs, and technical training for inspection and acceptance

title: First Chinese medical team completes stint at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Bridgetown Barbados (linked to #54835, #72188, #71321, and #54836)
description: On December 19, 2016, a welcome ceremony was held in Barbados for a team of 8 Chinese specialist medical personal sent by the Chongqing Municipal Health Commission. The eight-person team was comprised of 3 surgeons, 2 physicians, 1 anesthetist, 1 nephrologist and a critical nurse, all positions previously understaffed at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH). Their time in Barbados follows a pact signed by Barbados and China in October 2016 to expand medical exchange and cooperation. Both Chinese Ambassador Wang Ke and Barbadian Health Minister John Boyce indicated great satisfaction with the cooperation.   On July 14, 2017, they finished their stay at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) in Bridgetown, in a ceremony in which a second team replaced them. This is the first team of three to visit Queen Elizabeth Hospital from 2016-2018.   This team was the first of four batches and training provided by an October 2016 Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). See projects ID #54835, #54834, #71321, and #54836 for projects on each of the medical batches. #72188 captures the training provided through the agreement.
staff_comments: Barbados is not ODA-eligible from 2011 onwards.
combined_text:

justification: Project focuses on medical exchange and cooperation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare cooperation agreement, no energy-related components mentioned
